posts.name: Noah Miller
posts.cooked:
We are having an issue when connecting to the new radio from the driver station when having limelights being connected to the radio as well. Currently, our radio is wired using the REV radio power module connected to the RIO port on the radio. DIP switches 1 and 2 are set to off, and DIP switch 3 is set to on. We are running the newest firmware on the radio as well.

When connecting to the driver station with only the RIO connected to the radio, we do not experience any connection issues, however when we plug in a limelight to any aux or the DS port, when see large spikes in latency in the DS logs and constant disconnects from the driver station to the robot. We have tried both directly connecting limelights to the AUX ports and using a brainbox to connect to the limelights as well. Both ways resulted in the same issue. We have also tried going back to the old radios to see if it is an isolated issue with the new radio, or if it is present with both, and the old radio worked like normal, not having the disconnect issues.

I do want to note that at some point during the process, the radio was wired using both 12v from the PDH and 18v from the Rev radio power module. We haven’t ruled out if this is the culprit of the issue, but are open to any other suggestions on why this could be happening or how to fix it. We will be attending IRI later this week so any help for solutions is welcomed.

link_counts.title: [FRC Blog] New Radios at 2024 FIRST Championship

posts.name: RoboLancers 321 | LANCE-A-LOT 427 | FIRST Business Development Manager
posts.cooked: We had this issue as well. It turned out that our camera feed was saturating the connection on the new radio. I wasn’t involved in trouble shooting, but I believe the TL;DR is that the old radio had a very low hard cap on the bandwidth, whereas the new one doesn’t, and somewhere else in the process (driver station laptop, perhaps?), the extra data caused hiccups. I think we just disabled the feed to the laptop, since it wasn’t needed. I can pry more information from our programming team if needed, but I’d look there, since your issues sound VERY similar to what we were experiencing when trying to use the new radio at home (this issue did not happen in competition mode).
posts.display_username: RoboLancers 321 | LANCE-A-LOT 427 | FIRST Business Development Manager

posts.name: brian smith
posts.cooked:
Isriah:

I can pry more information from our programming team if needed,

Could you see if the programming team has any more input? We do have 2 limelights and can probably do without one of them, but we do need the other one. I think you can turn down the LL bandwidth but I thought we already did that given the old radios extremely limited bw (especially in competition).

Thanks!

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Unfortunately the combination of video streams, no bandwidth limiting, and 2.4 GHz AP mode is not a good one.  If you run with two radios (bridge on robot, AP on desk) you’ll almost certainly have enough bandwidth at 6 GHz for this to not be a problem (even though that combination also does not bandwidth limit).

posts.name: brian smith
posts.cooked:
We don’t seem to have any issues with the old radio running 2 LL cameras. Is there something with the new radio configuration that is an issue? There isn’t a lot of documentation on using the new radios outside of competitions unfortunately…

Thanks

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
The old radios have a 5 GHz on-robot AP mode, and have an option to bandwidth limit on the robot radio side.  The new radios have neither.

When the new radios are operating in 6 GHz mode (which is only possible with 2 radios: on-robot bridge and fixed AP), the new radios have a lot more bandwidth, so bandwidth limiting isn’t really needed for common use.  But when they’re operating in 2.4 GHz AP mode (the only option with only 1 on-robot radio), 2.4 GHz has significantly less bandwidth to work with, so the lack of bandwidth limiting is an issue.

posts.name: brian smith
posts.cooked:
Maybe a dumb question then… If we buy a Wifi 6E widget for our driver station laptop. can we operate the robot with the new radio at 6GHz?

We have several phones that do Wifi 6E/6GHz but the radio doesn’t appear to broadcast an SSID.

Is it possible to use the new radios at home?

Thanks.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
isubsmith:

the radio doesn’t appear to broadcast an SSID.

Due to regulatory reasons, 6GHz networks cannot be broadcast from battery-powered devices. This is why a second non-robot radio is necessary. Theoretically a different wall-powered 6GHz router could serve that purpose, but I don’t know if that’s supported.

posts.name: brian smith
posts.cooked:
so given the bandwidth issues Peter mentioned earlier and this regulation, the new radios are essentially worthless outside of competition unless we also buy an additional wifi6e access point of some sort?

I’m really uncomfortable having to rely on the “let’s just hope it works at competition since we can’t use it at home…” strategy.

Thanks.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
isubsmith:

We have several phones that do Wifi 6E/6GHz but the radio doesn’t appear to broadcast an SSID.

No, it’s not legal for a wifi 6e access point to be “mobile”, so the radio will not set one up when it’s on a robot, only when it’s in fixed mode plugged into a wall.

isubsmith:

the new radios are essentially worthless outside of competition unless we also buy an additional wifi6e access point of some sort?

Not worthless as they work okay without video streaming at 2.4 GHz, but if you want to do that, you pretty much need to buy a second radio to be the fixed AP.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
isubsmith:

let’s just hope it works at competition since we can’t use it at home

This is not really a change over the old situation, where the radios were 2.4 GHz at home and 5 GHz when in competition mode.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Actually, the old radios could be set up as a 5 GHz AP at home too.  They also bandwidth limited on the radio side so the video streams wouldn’t cause control packet issues.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: We almost never used the old radios in 2.4 mode. The old radios could be a 5G AP.

posts.name: seg9585
posts.cooked: I’m sorry, legality aside, how does the radio know it’s being powered by a battery?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: That’s a topic we don’t want to discuss in any detail.  This is the very first device that’s been approved by the FCC to operate in two different 6e modes based on application (fixed AP, mobile bridge); let’s not jeopardize that.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
isubsmith:

we also buy an additional wifi6e access point of some sort?

Such as a second copy of the same new radio, which IMO teams should already do so that they have a spare at comp… Is the plan anyway, I think the firmware to support this is coming towards the end of this month per kiets last post

posts.name: brian smith
posts.cooked: We ordered a 2nd competition radio, so maybe we’ll have to wait for this software update then…

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked:
s-neff:

Is the plan anyway, I think the firmware to support this is coming towards the end of this month per kiets last post

isubsmith:

so maybe we’ll have to wait for this software update then…

The new firmware is to be able to use a VH-109 as a multi SSID AP (like the Field AP)

You can bridge two radios together with the current firmware .

To do this configure the radio on the robot in “Team Client/STA Mode” (Robot Radio Mode). And configure the radio off the robot in “Team Access Point Mode” Make sure you enter the same WPA/SAE key on both radios. Then connect your driver station via ethernet to the radio that is off the robot. Once both radio’s power on they will bridge together, you can verify this by looking at the links on the radios.

Here is the radio programing documentation

Here is the LED status documentation

posts.name: Josh Sirota
posts.cooked:
We’ve been having these same issues with our new radio (and we have only one), and I just found this thread.

Am I missing something? The fact that one cannot reliably test one’s robot at home without (A) having two of these radios; and (B) hard-wiring the driver’s station to the wall-powered 2nd one, seems like a humongous miss.

The proposed answer not only requires teams to buy additional radios, but also requires us to basically build a new driver’s station that contains not just a laptop and a controller, but also contains its own radio, AND requires power to that driver’s station. In our shop, and I can’t imagine we’re the only ones, we generally have to test outdoors and far from power. Do I also understand that if we were to do this, we’d be violating FCC rules by broadcasting a 6GHz network outdoors?

Between this and having to handle the heat (holy crap it gets hot while it’s not working), it’s certainly not the compatible-with-the-old-one-but-better thing we were expecting. I hope there are new revisions that make this easier for teams.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
I don’t think this is necessarily a fair characterization.

with new technology there are always growing pains. Assume good intentions at the hand of our new radio vendor and that they are trying to make it as easy as possible. New features and firmware releases already and incoming with bug fixes and ease of use feature enhancements the community has been asking for after first contact with competition and robots. This is progress over a stagnant, persistently problematic component in the old radios.

If you choose to wait a new radio will be in the KOP . If you want to work ahead, they are already available for purchase in quantities FRC motor vendors and teams envy.

comparing apples to apples - the old radio and it’s forced BW limit made the expansion of cameras, multiple video feeds, etc…a problem brushed under the rug. It was always and is today still an issue with the 2.4GHz band on the old radios, you just didn’t know it because video feeds and frames were simply dropped and devices non-functional for streaming. Add the upside that the new radio on its 6GHz band will blow previous BW limits and data throughput out of the water enabling all of this advancement to have a shot at working at higher resolutions and frame rates when configured correctly…pushes the new solution again ahead of today’s radios.

comparing apples to apples - the old radio and it’s forced BW limit made the expansion of cameras, multiple video feeds, etc…a problem brushed under the rug. It was always and is today still an issue with the 2.4GHz band on the old radios, you just didn’t know it because video feeds and frames were simply dropped and devices non-functional for streaming. Add the upside that the new radio on its 6GHz band will blow previous BW limits and data throughput out of the water enabling all of this advancement to have a shot at working at higher resolutions and frame rates when configured correctly…pushes the new solution again ahead of today’s radios.

your concern about outdoors use and needing a dedicated power supply is valid…I’m personally interested/excited to create a new DS as ours is woefully…thrown together at the last second every year instead of something persistent/thought out…but it is one step back in ease-of-use compared to the old radio setup requiring some upgrade/redesign work from existing teams.

4)…you first need to make something functional before intterating and making it optimized. I’m glad we got something (and a decent/exceptional rev.A according to reviews from teams using the radio at Champs), and not nothing stuck in analysis paralysis.
